Effect of supported MAO cocatalysts in ethylene polymerization and ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization using Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) catalyst Dedicated to Professor Atsushi Fukuoka on the occasion of the 60th birthday in appreciation of his wonderful contribution to Molecular Catalysis. Palawat Unruean a b Wannida Apisuk c Youhei Kawabata c Toru Murayama c Boonyarach Kitiyanan a b Kotohiro Nomura c ⁎ a The Petroleum and Petrochemicals College, Chulalongkorn University, Soi Chulalongkorn 12, Phayathai Road, Pathumwan, Bangkok, 10330, Thailand The Petroleum and Petrochemicals College Chulalongkorn University Soi Chulalongkorn 12 Phayathai Road Pathumwan Bangkok 10330 Thailand b Center of Excellence on Petrochemical and Materials Technology, Chulalongkorn University Research Building, Soi Chulalongkorn 12, Phayathai Road, Pathumwan, Bangkok, 10330, Thailand Center of Excellence on Petrochemical and Materials Technology Chulalongkorn University Research Building Soi Chulalongkorn 12 Phayathai Road Pathumwan Bangkok 10330 Thailand c Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Tokyo Metropolitan University, 1-1 Minami Osawa, Hachioji, Tokyo, 192-0397, Japan Department of Chemistry Faculty of Science Tokyo Metropolitan University 1-1 Minami Osawa Hachioji Tokyo 192-0397 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Ethylene slurry polymerization using Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) in the presence of supported solid MAO cocatalysts proceeded without decrease in the activity compared to the homogeneous system; unique characteristics by 1 in the copolymerization with 1-hexene (activity, comonomer incorporation) observed in the homogeneous system have also been preserved. Ethylene slurry polymerization using Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) in the presence of supported solid MAO cocatalysts proceeded without decreasing in the activity compared to the homogeneous system, affording polymers with controlled shape replicated from the original support. Unique characteristics by 1 in the ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization observed in the homogeneous system (high catalytic activity, efficient 1-hexene incorporation, temperature dependence) have also been preserved in this catalysis, affording high molecular weight poly(ethylene-co-1-hexene)s with unimodal molecular weight distributions as well as with high 1-hexene contents. Keywords Titanium Supported catalyst Ethylene polymerization MAO Half-titanocenes Introduction Polyolefins exemplified as linear high density polyethylene (HDPE), linear low density polyethylene (LLDPE, copolymers with α-olefin), polypropylene (PP, isotactic polypropylene) etc., cover ca. 50% production of commercialized synthetic polymers in the world, and the transition metal catalyzed olefin polymerization is the core technology in chemical industry. Research subject on synthesis of new polymers, which cannot be (or are very difficult to be) prepared by the conventional catalysts (such as Ziegler-Natta, metallocenes, and linked half metallocenes called constrained geometry type etc.), by design of new efficient molecular catalysts [1–4] or by establishment of new methodologies [5] has thus been considered as an important topic in the field of catalysis, polymer chemistry, and of organometallic chemistry. Although the recent progress provides promising possibilities [3–5], most of these polymerizations were conducted in homogeneous system. In contrast, the homogeneous systems (called solution polymerization process) are generally limited to production of lower-crystallinity polymers in the commercial olefin polymerization process, and the slurry or gas phase processes have been employed for better process control not only of mass transport with better morphology without reactor fouling, but also control of temperature, productivity etc. [6]. Therefore, study on heterogenization of molecular catalysts over certain supports has been a topic of interests especially from the practical viewpoint [6–12]. It has been well known that spherical MgCl2-supported Ti-Al catalyst systems have been used in the commercialized Ziegler-Natta catalyst process [9,10], and that the career acts as a template for the product particle formation and the shape of the support is replicated during polymerization (upon growing the polymer particles) [6,9,10]; the similar replica effect was also observed in the Phillips catalysts, SiO2-supported Cr catalyst for ethylene polymerization [7,8]. Many studies on heterogenization of the transition metal complex catalysts have thus been reported [6–12], however, requirement of supporting catalysts has several drawbacks in terms of decrease in the activity and inferior capability of comonomer insertion (higher α-olefin etc.) in the copolymerization [6–8]. Therefore, development of heterogeneous olefin polymerization process (design of supported single site catalyst), which shows similar capability (activity and comonomer incorporation) in the homogeneous system, has been an attractive subject in the field of catalysis and polymer chemistry. Half-titanocenes containing anionic ancillary donor ligands, Cp’TiX2(Y) (Cp’ = cyclopentadienyl group, X = Cl, Me etc.; Y = phenoxide, ketimide, iminoimidazolide etc.) have been known to display unique characteristics as catalysts for olefin polymerization [3c,e,i]; both the phenoxide and the ketimide analogues exhibit efficient comonomer incorporations in the ethylene copolymerizations. In particular, Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (1) not only exhibited both high activities with efficient comonomer incorporations in the ethylene copolymerizations with higher α-olefins [13,14], but also demonstrated incorporation of branched α-olefins [14c,15a] and 2-methyl-1-pentene (1,1-disubstituted α-olefin) [16] that are very difficult (impossible) to be incorporated by the ordinary catalysts (Scheme 1 ). Moreover, catalysts of this type are also capable of incorporation of tert-butyl ethylene [15b], styrene [17], and with cyclic olefins [18] in the ethylene copolymerization by modification of substituents on the cyclopentadienyl ligand (such as t BuC5H4, 1,2,4-Me3C5H3, or indenyl). These (co)polymerizations were conducted in toluene in the presence of methylaluminoxane (MAO) cocatalyst, and no detailed studies using the supported systems have been done [19], whereas analogous half-titanocenes have been commercialized in industry, especially for production of synthetic rubbers (EPDM) [20]. MAO has been widely used as effective cocatalyst for olefin polymerization, and it has been known that ordinary (commercially available) MAO is a mixture of different oligomers including liner and some ring (cyclic and cage) structures (Scheme 2 ), and presents in the equilibria between the oligomers and complexation of the oligomers with each other and with unreacted AlMe3 [21]. Although the exact structure is still not clear at this moment, it has been postulated that the activity was affected by the MAO structure due to interaction of the proposed catalytically active species (cationic alkyl) with the MAO anion [1–6,21]. Recently, use of solid MAO (suspended slurry in hydrocarbon or toluene solution) in place of supported MAO on SiO2 etc. has been considered as an attractive cocatalyst for the above purpose [22]. This is because that (i) the process does not require the impregnation of complex catalyst (described below) which may cause decrease in the catalyst performances due to decomposition, (ii) certain decrease in the activity by preparation of supported MAO and/or re-activation by treatment of Al alkyls (often employed in the industrial process) would not be considered. As shown in Fig. 1 , SEM micrographs of the solid MAO support (called S4 in this paper, d(0.5) = 5.6 μm, prepared at Tosoh Finechem Corp.), the support is insoluble in organic solvent but acts as both cocatalysts and support in the slurry olefin polymerization process. Although use of these cocatalysts/supports seems interesting, there are several requirements to be confirmed concerning (i) replication effect (formation of spherical polymer particles during slurry polymerization without formation of fluffy materials by separation from the particles even in the fragmentation process, process of microparticle aggregates into nanoparticles) [9,10], (ii) catalyst performances. Although solid MAO has been known in chemical industry [22], reports concerning their performances still have been limited. Therefore, in this manuscript, we explored the possibility of using solid MAO support for ethylene polymerization and ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization using Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (1) catalyst (Scheme 3 ). Through this study, we wish to demonstrate that use of this solid MAO is useful for better morphology control with maintaining the catalyst performance (activity, comonomer incorporation) in these (co)polymerizations [23]. Experimental section General procedures All experiments were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere in a Vacuum Atmospheres drybox unless otherwise specified. All chemicals used were of reagent grades and were purified by the standard purification procedures. Anhydrous grade toluene (Kanto Chemical Co., Inc.) was transferred into a bottle containing molecular sieves (mixture of 3 Å 1/16 and 4 Å 1/8, and 13 × 1/16) under a nitrogen stream in the drybox, and was used without further purification. Reagent grade 1-hexene (Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd.) was stored in bottles in the drybox in the presence of molecular sieves. Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (1) was prepared according to previous report [13]. Ethylene for polymerization was of polymerization grade (purity >99.9%; Sumitomo Seika Co., Ltd.) and was used as received. All 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV 500 spectrometer (500.13 MHz for 1H; 125.77 MHz for 13C), and all chemical shifts are given in ppm and are referred to SiMe4. 13C NMR spectra for the resultant polymers were recorded with proton decoupling, and the pulse interval was 5.2 s, the acquisition time was 0.8 s, the pulse angle was 90°, and the number of transients accumulated was about 6000. The polymer samples for analysis were prepared by dissolving the polymers in CDCl3 solution, and the spectra was measured at 25 °C. Molecular weights and the molecular weight distributions of the resultant polymers were measured by gel-permeation chromatography (GPC). HPLC grade THF was used for GPC and was degassed prior to use. GPC was performed at 140 °C on a Tosoh HLC-8121GPC/HT using a RI-8022 detector (Tosoh Co.) in o-dichlorobenzene (containing 0.05 wt/v % of 2,6-di-tert-butyl-p-cresol) with a polystyrene gel columns (TSK gel GMHHR-H HT × 2, 30 cm ×7.8 mm diameter, ranging from <102 to <2.8 × 107 MW). The molecular weight was calculated by a standard procedure based on the calibration with standard polystyrene samples. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) (VE9800S, Keyence. Co., Japan) was used to observe morphology of the resultant polyethylene samples (Figs. 2 and 3). n-Hexane (S1-S3) or toluene (S4) slurry (suspension) of four different solid poly(methylaluminoxane) (PMAO) samples (solid MAO supports) [22c], prepared according to the following procedures (described below) [diameter, d(0.5): S1 = 5.7 μm, S2 = 11.6 μm, S3 = 21.7 μm, S4 = 5.6 μm; 39.8–41.4 wt%-Al in solid; Tosoh Finechem Co.], were used as white solids separated by decantation in the drybox. The resultant solids were then washed with n-hexane and was dried in vacuo. For comparison, toluene and AlMe3 in the commercially available methylaluminoxane [TMAO, 9.5 wt% (Al) toluene solution; Tosoh Finechem Co.] were taken to dryness under reduced pressure (at ca. 50 °C for removing toluene, AlMe3, and then heated at >100 °C for 1 h for completion) in the drybox to give white solids (expressed as d-MAO in this text) [13,24]. Measurements of the particle size distribution of the dry solid PMAO samples were conducted with a Master Sizer 2000 Hydro S as evaluated a volume based median diameter expressed as d(0.5). The specific surface area of the solid aluminoxane composition was determined using the gas absorption phenomenon in the solid surface by a BET adsorption isotherm using A BELLSORP mini II (BEL Japan, Inc.). SEM (VE7800, Keyence. Co., Japan) was used to observe morphology of solid MAO samples (S4, Fig. 1). Synthesis of solid poly(methylaluminoxane) (PMAO) sample (S1) Into a 2 L separable flask equipped with a mechanical stirrer, a toluene solution (600.5 g) containing AlMe3 (240.8 g, 3.34 mol) was added under nitrogen atmosphere and the solution was cooled at 15 °C. Benzoic acid (170.2 g, 1.39 mol) was then added slowly to control the stirred reaction mixture below 25 °C (the Al/O molar ratio of oxygen atoms in benzoic acid and AlMe3 was 1.20) [22c]. The mixture was then heated with stirring at 70 °C, and was continued for 32 h. The solution gave a transparent liquid free of gelled material, and the results of Al analysis conducted following recovery of the reaction solution indicated the quantitative reaction yield based on Al atoms (The Al concentration of the reaction solution obtained was 9.04 mass%). The above prepared PMAO (406.5 g, 1.361 mol-Al), placed into a 5 L separable flask equipped with a mechanical stirrer, was heated for 8 h at 100 °C. A solid PMAO composition was precipitated during heating, and the resultant mixture was then cooled to below 30 °C and was added 3.6 L of n-hexane with stirring for washing. The supernatant was then removed and the resultant solid was washed twice with 3 L of n-hexane. The resultant solid was dried under a reduced pressure at room temperature affording a solid PMAO particles, and the precipitation ratio of the dried solid PMAO was 96% based on Al atoms in the PMAO composition in solution employed. Al content in the solid was 40.9 wt.%. Diameter, d(0.5) = 5.7 μm, surface area 570 m2/g, pore volume 0.291 cm3/g. Synthesis of PMAO composition in solution (S2) Preparation of S2 was conducted similarly to that conducted for S1, except that benzoic acid (176.3 g, 1.44 mol) was added and the reaction mixture was heated at 60 °C instead of 70 °C (the Al/O molar ratio of oxygen atoms in benzoic acid and AlMe3 was 1.18). Al content in the resultant solid was 39.8 wt.%. Diameter, d(0.5) = 11.6 μm. Synthesis of PMAO composition in solution (S3) Preparation of S3 was conducted similarly to that conducted for S1, except that benzoic acid (176.3 g, 1.44 mol) was added and the reaction mixture was heated at 60 °C (the Al/O molar ratio was 1.25). Al content in the resultant solid was 41.7 wt.%. Diameter, d(0.5) = 21.7 μm. Synthesis of PMAO composition in solution (S4) Preparation of S4 was conducted similarly to that conducted for S1, except that benzoic acid (176.3 g, 1.44 mol) was added (the Al/O molar ratio was 1.18). Al content in the resultant solid was 39.8 wt.%. Diameter, d(0.5) = 5.6 μm. Ethylene polymerization and ethylene 1-hexene copolymerization Ethylene polymerizations were conducted in toluene (or n-heptane) by using a 100 mL scale autoclave. Solvent (29.0 mL) and prescribed amount of solid MAO, prepared by the procedure described above, were charged into the autoclave in the drybox, and the apparatus was placed under ethylene atmosphere (1 atm). After the addition of a toluene solution (1.0 mL) containing a prescribed amount of Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (1) via a syringe, the reaction apparatus was pressurized to 5 atm (total 6 atm), and the mixture was stirred magnetically for 10 min. After the above procedure, ethylene was purged, and the mixture was then poured into MeOH (150 mL) containing HCl (10 mL). The resultant polymer was collected on a filter paper by filtration and was adequately washed with MeOH and then dried in vacuo. Experimental procedure for ethylene/1-hexene copolymerizations were the same as those for the ethylene polymerizations except that a prescribed amount of 1-hexene was charged and the total volume of toluene and 1-hexene was set to 30.0 mL. Results and discussion Ethylene polymerization using Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (1) in the presence of solid MAO supports Four solid MAO supports with different particle sizes, S1-3 [n-hexane slurry, d(0.5) = 5.7 (S1), 11.6 (S2), and 21.7 (S3) μm] and S4 [toluene slurry, d(0.5) = 5.6 μm, shown in Fig. 1], have been chosen in this study. As described in the experimental section, these MAO supports (S1-S4), which are insoluble in organic solvent probably due to partial cross-linking and/or further network structures, were prepared by treatment of AlMe3 with benzoic acid [22c]. It was reported that the treatment temperature and the Al/O ratio affect the diameter and nature of the resultant solid MAO supports [22]; the reaction at high temperature afforded the sample with high degree of Al-O bond (tend to afford small particle size, S1, S4 compared to S2 and S3) and the preparation with high Al/O molar ratio affords the sample with large diameter (S3) probably due to rather weak Al-O network (S3 thus possesses the most weak network structure among the others, whereas S4 thus possesses the most strongest network structure). These samples, however, did not show any significant differences in the specific surface area measured by the gas absorption phenomenon in the solid surface by a BET adsorption isotherm [22]. MAO white solid (d-MAO), prepared by removing toluene and AlMe3 from the commercially available MAO, employed in the homogeneous system [13–18,24] was also used for comparison. Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (1) has been chosen, because, as described in the introductory, 1 exhibits remarkably high activity for ethylene polymerization [13] and promising capability of activity and comonomer incorporation in ethylene/α-olefin copolymerizations [13–16]. The results in ethylene polymerization are summarized in Table 1 . It should be noted that 1 showed high catalytic activities in the presence of supported MAO (S1), and the activities in toluene (40700–70200 kg-PE/mol-Ti·h, runs 1–4) are similar or rather higher than that conducted in the presence of ordinary MAO (d-MAO, 49,800 kg-PE/ mol-Ti·h, run 5). The activity by 1-S1 catalyst was affected by Al/Ti molar ratios (amount of S1 employed) and solvent; the activity conducted in heptane showed lower than those conducted in toluene (runs 6,7 vs runs 1–4). It also turned out that the activity was affected by the MAO particle size (runs 8–10), and use of S2 [d(0.5) = 11.6 μm] showed the low activity compared to the others (S1, S3 and S4). The observed activities in the presence of S1-3 are similar or rather higher than that conducted in ordinary MAO (runs 8–11). It should be noted that use of S4, which would possess the most strong Al-O network structure [22], showed the highest catalytic activity in the ethylene polymerization. The activity increased upon increasing the Al/Ti molar ratio and the ethylene pressure; the activity also increased at high temperature (50 °C, runs 12–19 vs runs 20–25, except runs 26,27). Although the reason for the low activity (runs 26,27) is unclear, one probable reason might be speculated as due to the partial catalyst decomposition owing to difficulty of ethylene difusion toward the active species located on the solid MAO surface. Importantly, as demonstrated in Table 1, these polymerization results are reproducible. Fig. 2 shows SEM images in the resultant polyethylene (PE) prepared by 1 in the presence of S1-3 (Fig. 2a-c), and d-MAO (Fig. 2d). It is clear that the polymerization in the presence of solid MAO supports afforded spherical PE particles without by production of fluffy materials. The PE particle size increased upon increasing the size of the MAO support (S1 < S2 < S3), and the results clearly indicate that the MAO acts as a template for the product particle formation and the shape of the support is replicated during polymerization. In contrast, as shown in Fig. 2d, the resultant polymers are entangled as a mixture of probably (fluffy) polymer chains, clearly suggesting the existence of replica effect in the presence of S1-3 (Fig. 2a–c). SEM images in the resultant polyethylene (PE) prepared by 1 in the presence of S4 under various conditions. Importantly, the observed replicated effect was maintained irrespective of Al/Ti molar ratios, ethylene pressure (4 or 6 atm), and polymerization temperature (25 or 50 °C). The resultant PE particles are spherical with controlled shape, and fluffy polymer chains that will cause reactor fouling were not seen. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 4 , size in the resultant spherical particles (3.795 ± 0.996 μm) were relatively uniform. Taking into account the SEM images in Fig. 1 (S4 before polymerization) and Fig. 3, it is clear that these polymerizations proceeded in slurry phase and the S4 play a role as a support template for growing the PE polymer chains from the MAO particle surface by interacting with the catalytically active species [should be cationic Ti(IV) alkyls] formed from 1. Copolymerization of ethylene with 1-hexene using Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (1) in the presence of solid MAO supports On the basis of the above ethylene polymerization results, ethylene/1-hexene copolymerizations by 1 were conducted in the presence of solid MAO supports. The results are summarized in Table 2 . It turned out that the observed activities in the copolymerizations using 1–S1 catalyst at 25 °C (runs 28–30, 10500–37300 kg-polymer/mol-T·h) are rather low compared to those in the ethylene polymerization (40700–62000 kg-polymer/mol-T·h, runs 1–4, Table 1), whereas significant increase in the activity was observed in the homogeneous system upon addition of 1-hexene [14a,b] and even higher α-olefins [14c]. The activity by 1–S1 catalyst increased at 40 °C, and with increasing 1-hexene charged (runs 31–32). The resultant polymers possessed high molecular weights with unimodal molecular weight distributions, which are similar to those in the homogeneous systems [14b]. In contrast, 1–S2 catalyst showed higher catalytic activities than 1–S1 catalyst [ex. activity 37,300 kg-polymer/mol-T·h (run 30) vs 122,000 kg-polymer/mol-T·h (run 33)]. The observed activities by 1-S2 catalyst in the copolymerization are higher than that in the ethylene polymerization, as observed in the homogeneous system [14a,b]. The activity was affected by Al/Ti molar ratios (runs 35–37), and the activity at 60 °C (run 34) was higher than that conducted at 25 °C (run 33). One probable reason for the observed higher activity by 1–S2 catalyst than 1–S1 catalyst in the copolymerization might be speculated as due to better access of monomers (especially 1-hexene, run 30 vs run 36) to the catalyst surface owing to their rather weak Al-O network in S2 compared to S1. It should be noted that 1–S4 catalyst showed the high catalytic activities, affording high molecular weight poly(ethylene-co-1-hexene)s with unimodal molecular weight distributions [M w = 1.19–1.50 × 105, M w/M n = 1.43–1.70]. The activity was affected by Al/Ti molar ratios (amount of S4) employed (runs 38–41, 42–46), whereas the M n values in the resultant copolymers were not affected by the amount of Al. These results thus suggest that the copolymerization proceeded with uniform catalytically active species and the major chain transfer in the copolymerization would not be the chain transfer to Al (but probably β-hydrogen elimination in high certainty). Importantly, the activity in the copolymerization increased at 50 °C without significant decreases in the M w values in the resultant copolymers. Moreover, as shown in Table 2, 1-hexene content in the copolymers were not strongly affected by the solid MAO cocatalyst employed (except probably S1) as well as the polymerization temperature (25 or 50 °C). Fig. 5 shows a selected 13C NMR spectrum (in C6D6/1,3,4-trichlorobenzene at 110 °C) for poly(ethylene-co-1-hexene) prepared by Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (1)–S1 catalyst (run 36, 1-hexene 38.9 mol%). All resonances are clearly assigned as isolated and alternating 1-hexene insertions (resonances corresponding alternating 1-hexene insertion: marked in TEHE, αγ, ββ, Fig. 4) in addition to resonances ascribed to 1-hexene repeated insertion (marked in TEHH+HHE, αα). The spectrum thus clearly indicates that the resultant polymer is poly(ethylene-co-1-hexene) with random 1-hexene incorporation (as also described below), as observed in the copolymers prepared by the homogeneous system [14]. Table 3 summarizes the triad sequence distribution, the dyads, r E, r H, and r E·r H values on the basis of microstructure analysis estimated by the 13C NMR spectra [25,26]. It should be noted that the r E values by 1–S1, 1–S2, and 1–S4 catalysts are 2.17–2.80, which are very close to those observed in the homogeneous system [14b]. The r E·r H values are 0.46-0.66, and the results thus clearly suggest that these copolymerizations proceed in a random manner (1-hexene incorporations are random in the copolymerization). The r E values (r E = 2.17–2.80) were not affected by the MAO supports employed and are close to those in the homogeneous systems; the r E values are smaller than those in ordinary metallocenes (r E = 6.45–18.9) [27] as well as linked half-titanocenes (r E = 3.42) [14b]. These results thus strongly suggest that 1 is capable of efficient 1-hexene incorporation and the unique characteristics (capability of efficient comonomer incorporations) are preserved even in the heterogeneous systems in the presence of supported MAO cocatalysts. Concluding remarks We have shown that solid supported MAO cocatalysts (S1-S4) can be used for ethylene polymerization using Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) (1), and the observed activities in the presence of S1-4 are similar or higher than that conducted in ordinary MAO (homogeneous system). The activity was affected by the MAO particle size (nature of MAO particles assumed as related to the network Al-O structure), Al/Ti molar ratios, solvent, and by polymerization temperature. On the basis of SEM images in the resultant polymers, it has been demonstrated that the polymerization in the presence of solid MAO supports afforded spherical PE particles without by production of fluffy materials, clearly indicating that the MAO acts as a template for the product particle formation and the shape of the support is replicated during polymerization. The observed replicated effect was maintained irrespective of Al/Ti molar ratios, ethylene pressure (4 or 6 atm), and polymerization temperature (25 or 50 °C). It is thus clear that these polymerizations proceeded in slurry phase and the MAO play a role as a support template for growing the polymer chains from the particle surface by interacting with the catalytically active species [should be cationic Ti(IV) alkyls] formed from 1. Noteworthy, the solid supported MAO cocatalysts (S1-S4, especially S2 and S4) can also be used for the ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization by 1 without diminishing the unique catalyst performances (catalytic activity especially by S2 and S4, capability of 1-hexene incorporation evaluated as r E values). As described in the introductory, in spite of many reports on heterogenization of transition metal complex catalysts [6–12], supported catalysts often have several concerns compared to the homogeneous systems in terms of not only decrease in the activity, but also inferior capability of comonomer incorporation in the copolymerization [6–8]. Moreover, the present supported catalyst does not require impregnation process which might cause the deactivation by interaction of catalytically active species with inorganic support. Therefore, we believe that these information should be helpful and important for better design of efficient molecular catalysis applied to heterogeneous system especially in terms of practical applications with better morphology and thermal controls with high productivity. Ethylene concentrations under the reaction conditions were estimated by the equation quoted by Kissin (Y.V. Kissin, Isospecific Polymerization of Olefin with Heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta Catalysts, Springer-Verlag, NewYork, 1985), and the ethylene solubilities in the reaction mixture (1 atm) were used as those in toluene reported in the following article Can. J. Chem. Eng. 56 1978 354 357 [27] (a) J. Suhm M.J. Schneider R. Mülhaupt J. Polym. Sci. Part A Polym. Chem. 35 1997 735 740 (b) J. Suhm M.J. Schneider R. Mülhaupt J. Mol. Catal. A Chem. 128 1998 215 227

coredata.dc:description: Ethylene slurry polymerization using Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) in the presence of supported solid MAO cocatalysts proceeded without decreasing in the activity compared to the homogeneous system, affording polymers with controlled shape replicated from the original support. Unique characteristics by 1 in the ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization observed in the homogeneous system (high catalytic activity, efficient 1-hexene incorporation, temperature dependence) have also been preserved in this catalysis, affording high molecular weight poly(ethylene-co-1-hexene)s with unimodal molecular weight distributions as well as with high 1-hexene contents.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of supported MAO cocatalysts in ethylene polymerization and ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization using Cp*TiCl2(O-2,6- i Pr2C6H3) catalyst
